channel.title: Real 194 Server and Client [Good Luck :D]
channel.description:
Hello there, this is Taharok, Grahams, and etc.'s REAL REALLY REALLY REAL 194 server and client. 99.9999999% credits to them. I did nothing but fix a few errors in the client and make a item id list from 0-200...
This release does have shell files (.sh) and is pretty easy to get going.
[size=18pt]I released this because I really hope someone can load 289 map data onto it (objects) and also get far.[/size]
[IMG]http://i58.tinypic.com/2q2qna1.png[/img]
[IMG]http://i60.tinypic.com/25j9h15.png[/img]
[IMG]http://i62.tinypic.com/b47v60.png[/img]
[IMG]http://i62.tinypic.com/dy1uhl.png[/img]
[IMG]http://i60.tinypic.com/1444h8i.png[/img]
[IMG]http://i61.tinypic.com/2uf67tk.png[/img]
On Mediafire: http://www.mediafire.com/download/tuym577peyhrv7i/RS2-Beta_rev_194.zip
If someone could mirror it at uppit and stuff please go ahead.
[quote="Encryption"][size=18pt]Oh lord, that's nice. Good luck to anyone using this, going to need a lot of work and patience.[/size][/quote]
[size=18pt]Good Luck if you take this seriously.[/size]

item.title: Real 194 Server and Client [Good Luck :D]
item.dc:creator: @Minigame Minigame
item.description:
@Minigame wrote:

Here’s a little something I produced during the 1 week span I spent playing around with OP’s release… Anybody who is actively developing a 194 server will likely find this useful whether it be using the sql tables for your server, or just wanting a moderately aesthetic configuration list

I dumped some data from the 194 cache, converted the information to sql, and created a standalone webpage. Pic included in my thread:

moparisthebest.com

moparisthebest.com

programming, irc, cars

item.title: Real 194 Server and Client [Good Luck :D]
item.dc:creator: @Minigame Minigame
item.description:
@Minigame wrote:

I’m not one to bump threads, but I mean… I just signed up to say thank you for your efforts and for releasing this project. I will be playing around with it off and on, although I do plan on just porting the login/rendering/any working packets into a more aesthetic server framework :rolleyes:

I want to see this go somewhere. So… I’ll share this repo url I found, which is a fully refactored 194 client (which I think loads 317 map files) https://github.com/thedaneeffect/RS194

By the way OP, when you say you “fixed some client errors” what exactly do you mean? I’d like to know every client modification you had to make - or any server ‘hacks’ that had to be done to get rendering etc. (Like how wL disabled RSA for example)

Cheers, Minigame

Edit:
It looks like you patched the client to use the 317 login protocol, I discovered this during a stressful attempt to get Dane’s 194 client connecting… So I patched the login code and the handshake is able to be completed… Now I’m getting some horribly unusual errors, here is one of them and I’m not sure why these particular errors are happening, here’s one for example:

SEVERE: Error handling packet: 85
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: 5000
	at com.jagex.runetek3.Buffer.getString(Buffer.java:180)

Needless to say it’s going to be nearly impossible for anybody who’s not very experienced to get their own clients working with the server - I’m giving it an attempt - but it’s starting to consume way too much of my limited free time.
So I need to ask … Exactly how much of the protocol did you change, because getting any 194 client (besides the one you released) is becoming a major hassle :palm: It would be HIGHLY APPRECIATED if you could share notes about the changes you made.

…I guess anybody with enough motivation will figure it out though, aye?

Read full topic

item.title: Real 194 Server and Client [Good Luck :D]
item.dc:creator: @Fabrice_L Fabrice L
item.description:
@Fabrice_L wrote:

[quote=“Limits, post:29, topic:540280”][quote author=Fabrice L link=topic=659138.msg4432190#msg4432190 date=1403721266]

If you remember Azureify #194. I’m the one who worked on that project. Since I feel generous today, I thought I would comment on this thread. The map data was stored on the server back in 2003-04 thus, we don’t have the actual 194 maps. (Unless someone saved them in a vault somewhere)

I did however succeed in loading 289 maps on an actual 194 client. I loaded 289 models, and object definitions because the models/objects changed between 194-289. Then I dumped the 289 maps/landscapes from the cache and renamed the individual files into a format readable by the 194 client.

I don’t remember the individual packet ids and structures off the top of my head. But here is a rough diagram.

1. On login, a map region packet is sent from the server to the client.
2. If client is missing map data, the client sends a packet to the server requesting the map data. (Skips this step if the maps have already been downloaded by the client from the server)
2.1. Server sends map, and landscape data to the client to be cached. 
3. Player and NPC render packets sent
4. Magic (Landscapes and players visible on screen)

The server has the maps.

This works just like back on RSC I guess, the server is sending the coordinates and id of the object/texture/whatever to be loaded.
This is sent to the client and has nothing to do with the server from that moment on, since both objectmodels/textures and all other stuff are in the client’s cache anyway
[/quote]

You’re not dead! How’s it been?[/quote]

Who said I’m dead? been busy lately, that’s all

Read full topic

I don’t remember the individual packet ids and structures off the top of my head. But here is a rough diagram.

1. On login, a map region packet is sent from the server to the client.
2. If client is missing map data, the client sends a packet to the server requesting the map data. (Skips this step if the maps have already been downloaded by the client from the server)
2.1. Server sends map, and landscape data to the client to be cached. 
3. Player and NPC render packets sent
4. Magic (Landscapes and players visible on screen)

[/quote]

The server has the maps.

This works just like back on RSC I guess, the server is sending the coordinates and id of the object/texture/whatever to be loaded.
This is sent to the client and has nothing to do with the server from that moment on, since both objectmodels/textures and all other stuff are in the client’s cache anyway[/quote]

You’re not dead! How’s it been?

I did however succeed in loading 289 maps on an actual 194 client. I loaded 289 models, and object definitions because the models/objects changed between 194-289. Then I dumped the 289 maps/landscapes from the cache and renamed the individual files into a format readable by the 194 client.

I don’t remember the individual packet ids and structures off the top of my head. But here is a rough diagram.

[code]

  1. On login, a map region packet is sent from the server to the client.
  2. If client is missing map data, the client sends a packet to the server requesting the map data. (Skips this step if the maps have already been downloaded by the client from the server)

item.title: Real 194 Server and Client [Good Luck :D]
item.dc:creator: @jediz Sapphirus
item.description:
@jediz wrote:

If you remember Azureify #194. I’m the one who worked on that project. Since I feel generous today, I thought I would comment on this thread. The map data was stored on the server back in 2003-04 thus, we don’t have the actual 194 maps. (Unless someone saved them in a vault somewhere)

I did however succeed in loading 289 maps on an actual 194 client. I loaded 289 models, and object definitions because the models/objects changed between 194-289. Then I dumped the 289 maps/landscapes from the cache and renamed the individual files into a format readable by the 194 client.

I don’t remember the individual packet ids and structures off the top of my head. But here is a rough diagram.

1. On login, a map region packet is sent from the server to the client.
2. If client is missing map data, the client sends a packet to the server requesting the map data. (Skips this step if the maps have already been downloaded by the client from the server)
2.1. Server sends map, and landscape data to the client to be cached. 
3. Player and NPC render packets sent
4. Magic (Landscapes and players visible on screen)

item.title: Real 194 Server and Client [Good Luck :D]
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Fabrice L, post:24, topic:540280”][quote author=Docent link=topic=659138.msg4420352#msg4420352 date=1398091549]

[size=18pt]I released this because I really hope someone can load 289 map data onto it (objects) and also get far.[/size]

Looking at this, I noticed that there’s a big possibility that the objects still load like they did on the RuneScape Classic revision, thus being sent by the server.

Honestly I think you’re right and that’s why working off of this would be so hard.
[/quote]

Or you convert the objectloading from rscd to work with this I’ll take a fast look at it[/quote]

Please do it’d be one of the best things ever if someone was to do this. Also I remember looking in the code to see where the previous person was working (either Taharok or Graham) and I saw a method that wasn’t functioning properly with a commented out line above it like “//Todo: fix maps” and well at least I found where it would be at haha

Read full topic
